bibl.title: Letter from A. T. Gilhus to Philip Showalter Hench, November 20, 1946

div1.p: Gilhus relates his experiences at Camp Columbia and describes the camp in detail.

div1.head: Letter from A. T. Gilhus to Philip Showalter Hench, November 20, 1946
div1.opener:
1779 34th Ave, SF 22, Calif.
20th Nov. 1946.
Dr. Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic, Rochester, Minn.
Dear Doctor Hench:-
div1.p:
Your very nice letter of July 29th was duly received, and
I was pleased that the old photo of 2nd Div. Hosp. 7th Army
Corps was received with such enthsiasm.

I regret to have to admit that my personal recollections
in connection with the fight on yellow fever at the time
amounts to practically nothing; I only remember a few hos-
pital corps men bragging about being “immunes”; they were
detailed to nurse yellow fever patients accross the road
and considered themselves somewhat superior.

General Truby insisted the other night (at Gen. Hillman's
farewell party at LGH) that I should give you any clue-
no matter how insignificant it might appear to me- that
might assist you in your work. As I returned to the States
late in April, 1899, they are very slim. However, during the
past few years I have met people who served there during
the period in question. Firstly, there is Dr. Ira C. Brown,
who as major of Volunteers served as commanding officer of
the hospital while I was stationed there. He told me that
he had been sanitary inspector of schools in Seattle since
- oh, many years anyway. If he is still alive he should
be able to furnish much light on the subject.

Then there were a couple nurses, whlose names I do not recol-
lect but might be traced. One was chief nurse at the Ancon
(now Gorgas) Hospital. Whaen I left there in 1927 she told
me that she was to retire soon and expected to spend the rest
of her days in Jamaica, BWI.--- The other one I met in
Washington D.C. 1934 or 5; she had just been elected presi-
dent of the Daughters of the Confederacy. Both had served
at the 2nd Div. Hosp.

Mrs. Clarence Manly gave me a book of snaps from Cuba (98-99)
when the colonel passed on a few years ago. He was a dashing
young contract doctor at that time, but I had the provilege
of serving under him at Fort Benning and later here in SF.
I note that there are some pictures of the hospital in the
middle of the book. I am sending them to you for what they
may be worth.

Colonel Alexander Stark died many years ago, but his wife is
still living in Washington, DC. She must have been down there
at the time. General Truby's book has a picture of her sons
in a goat cart tied underneath a tree outside the administr-
tion tent. The elder one, Alec, was recently retired as B.G.
Dr. Hench -2- 20 Nov. 46
Young Col. Tom is still with Gen. Mc.Arthur, or maybe in
the P.I's. Incidentally, they were both born the same year.

Those nice wooden buildings in the foreground were built by
the 2nd Engineers. There were some choice sleeping quarters u
underneath some of them for which we fought before we got
ytents to sleep in. A tall wooden scaffold was erected
for the purpose of taking the Picture. Messes and sinks
were farther down the hill. and we passed the wooden build-
ings several times a day. The SURGERY shack shows only the
back side in the picture. The main sign was on the other
side and proclaimed it to be “surgery.” The first patient,
I believe, was a corps-man, who had been caught in a compro-
mising position by a husband, who did a clean job of hacking
his back and fanny with a machete. The poor lad found out
that the ladies were not so free and easy as some one had told
him. Another patient, about the same time, was an orderly
who had shot himself in the belly while cleaning an officer's
pistol. I am quite certain that Gen Kean (then major K.)
operated on both of these two men. I am sure that the front
end of the building had the sign “SURGERY” over the door, and
quite sure that a somewhat smaller one was nailed over the
rear door- the one that appears in the picture. It was indeed
“Major Kean's Workshop!”

A road ran back of the tents on the right hand side; it went
between Quemados and ???Mananao The 1st Missouri had a guard
company near that road. The yellow fever tents were farther
down- out of the picture on the right. The nurses tents
were upper left.
div1.closer:
With best wishes I remain
sincerely yours, A.T. Gilhus A.T. Gilhus
Sending Col. Manley's book under
separate cover
A.E.T.
